questions.label: What is the name of your innovation?
questions.description: Enter the name of your innovation with a maximum of 100 characters

questions.label: Provide a short description of your innovation
questions.description: Provide a high-level overview of your innovation. You will have the opportunity to explain its impact, target population, testing and revenue model later in the innovation record.

questions.label: Where is your head office located?
questions.description:
If your head office is overseas but you have a UK office, use the UK address.

If you are not part of a company or organisation, put where you are based.

We ask this to identify the organisations and people who are in the best position to support you.

items.label: I'm based outside of the UK

questions.label: What is your head office postcode?
Which country is your head office located in?
Does your innovation have a website?
Select all the categories that can be used to describe your innovation

items.label: Models of care and clinical pathways

questions.label: Select a primary category to describe your innovation
Is your innovation relevant to any of the following areas?
questions.description: We ask this to identify the organisations and people who are in the best position to support you.

items.label: Net zero NHS or greener innovation

questions.label: In which care settings is your innovation relevant?

validations.isRequired: Other care setting description is required

questions.label: What is the main purpose of your innovation?
questions.description: We ask this to identify the organisations and people who are in the best position to support you.

items.label: Preventing a condition or symptom from happening or worsening
Predicting the occurence of a condition or symptom
Monitoring a condition, treatment or therapy
Supporting the NHS to mitigate the risks or effects of climate change and severe weather conditions

questions.label: What support are you seeking from the Innovation Service?
questions.description:
For example, support with clinical trials, product development, real-world evidence, regulatory advice, or adoption.

You will have the opportunity to explain how your innovation works and its benefits later in the record

questions.label: Are you currently receiving any support for your innovation?
questions.description: This can include any UK funding to support the development of your innovation, or any support you are currently receiving from NHS Innovation Service organisations (opens in a new window).

questions.label: Are you involved with any Accelerated Access Collaborative programmes?
questions.description: Select all that apply, or select no, if not relevant.

items.label: Artificial Intelligence in Health and Care Award

subSections.title: Detailed understanding of needs and benefits (V3)

questions.label: What problem is your innovation trying to solve?
questions.description:
Include the current consequences of the problem.

For example, the process of checking a patient's pulse to determine if there is atrial fibrillation using a finger and a watch is inherently inaccurate. Using this method approximately 25% of patients are not referred to secondary care who should be (false negative) and 15% of patients who are referred are referred unnecessarily (false positive). For those patients who are not picked up at this stage, their underlying disease will progress before being correctly diagnosed.

questions.label: Give an overview of how your innovation works
questions.description:
If this is or might be a medical device, include the intended purpose statement (opens in a new window).

For example, GPs will identify patients with suspected atrial fibrillation from their history and reported symptoms. This innovation is a portable device that patients wear over a 7-day period. The device will monitor the patient’s heart rate continuously whilst they are wearing it. GPs will need to be trained in using the device and interpreting the results. GP practices will need to store the device and consumables.

questions.label: Do you have a working product, service or prototype?
What are the benefits or impact of your innovation?

questions.label: Have you estimated the carbon reduction or savings that your innovation will bring?
questions.description:
All NHS suppliers will be expected to provide the carbon footprint associated with the use of their innovation, as outlined in the Delivering a Net Zero NHS report (opens in a new window).

If this is something you are unsure of, the NHS Innovation Service can support you with this.

items.label: Not yet, but I have an idea

questions.label: Provide the estimates and how this was calculated
Explain how you plan to calculate carbon reduction savings
Do you have or are you working on a carbon reduction plan (CRP)?
questions.description: All NHS suppliers will require a carbon reduction plan (CRP), as outlined in the NHS Suppliers Roadmap plan (opens in a new window).

items.label: No, I do not have one

questions.label: Which key health inequalities does your innovation impact?
questions.description:
Core20PLUS5 is a national NHS England approach to support the reduction of health inequalities, defining target populations and clinical areas that require improvement.

More information is available on the Core20PLUS5 web page (opens in a new window).

items.label: Hypertension case finding and optimal management and lipid optimal management

questions.label: Have you completed a health inequalities impact assessment?
questions.description:
By this, we mean a document or template which assesses the impact of your innovation on health inequalities and on those with protected characteristics. Health inequalities are the unfair and avoidable differences in health across the population, and between different groups within society.

An example of a completed health inequalities impact assessment can be found on NHS England's web page (opens in a new window).

questions.label: Do you have any evidence to show the impact or benefits of your innovation?
questions.description: You'll have the opportunity to add evidence at the end of this section.

questions.label: Are you currently collecting evidence, or have plans to collect evidence?
Write a short summary of your ongoing or planned evidence gathering, including the IRAS number if known.
questions.description: An IRAS ID is a unique identifier, which is generated by IRAS when you first create a project. It is the accepted common study identifier, allowing research to be traced across its study lifecycle. For more information visit the IRAS website (opens in a new window).

questions.label: Do you need support with any of these areas?

items.label: Research governance, including research ethics approvals
Accessing and sharing health and care data
Understanding the laws that regulate the use of health and care data
No, I do not need support

sections.title: Market research and current care pathway (V3)

questions.label: Have you conducted market research to determine the demand and need for your innovation in the UK?
questions.description: By this, we mean any research you have done to determine the market opportunity for your innovation. You will be able to explain any testing you have done with users later in the record.

questions.label: Describe the market research you have done, or are doing, within the UK market
questions.description: This could include a mix of interviews, focus groups, patient record forms, surveys, ethnography, or other market research methods.

questions.label: Which option best describes your innovation?

items.label: A one-off innovation, or the first of its kind
A better alternative to those that already exist
An equivalent alternative to those that already exist
A more cost-effect alternative to those that already exist

questions.label: What competitors or alternatives exist, or how is the problem addressed in current practice?
questions.description: Include how your innovation is different to the alternatives in the market.

questions.label: Does your innovation relate to a current NHS care pathway?
questions.description:
An NHS care pathway outlines the entire patient journey and the actions taken in different parts of the healthcare system. It's key to understand the existing routines of clinical and care professionals, administrators and others who will be impacted by your innovation.

If your innovation does not play a role in the delivery of care, select "does not form part of a care pathway".

items.label: There is a pathway, and my innovation changes it
There is a pathway, and my innovation fits in to it
There is no current care pathway
Does not form part of a care pathway

questions.label: Describe the potential care pathway with your innovation in use
questions.description: Focus on any areas that will be impacted by introducing your innovation to the care pathway.

questions.label: Have you involved users in the design process?
questions.description: This includes involving patients or the public, carers, clinicians or administrators in the design process, including people with different accessibility needs.

items.label: A one-off innovation, or the first of its kind
I am in the process of involving users in the design

questions.label: Have you tested your innovation with its intended users in a real life setting?
questions.description: Do not include any testing you have done with users in a controlled setting.

items.label: I am in the process of testing with users

questions.label: Which groups of intended users have you engaged with?

items.label: Clinical or social care professionals working in the UK health and social care system
Clinical or social care professionals working outside the UK

questions.label: What kind of testing with users have you done?
questions.description: This can include any testing you have done with people who would use your innovation, for example patients, nurses or administrative staff.

addQuestion.label: Describe the testing and feedback for {{item.kind}}
addQuestion.description: Provide a brief summary of the method and key findings. You can upload any documents that showcase your user testing next.

sections.title: Regulations, standards, certifications and intellectual property (V3)

questions.label: Do you know which regulations, standards and certifications apply to your innovation?
questions.description: Find out more about regulations (opens in a new window).

items.label: Yes, I know all of them
Yes, I know some of them

questions.label: Which regulations, standards and certifications apply to your innovation?
questions.description: Find out more about UKCA / CE marking (opens in a new window), CQC registration (opens in a new window), or DTAC (opens in a new window).

addQuestion.label: Do you have a certification for {{item}}

items.label: I am actively working towards it
Care Quality Commission (CQC) registration, as I am providing a regulated activity

conditional.label: Other regulations, standards and certifications that apply

validations.isRequired: Other regulations, standards and certifications is required

questions.label: Do you have any patents for your innovation?

items.label: I have one or more patents
I have applied for one or more patents
I do not have any patents, but believe I have freedom to operate

questions.label: Do you have any other intellectual property for your innovation?
questions.description: Find out more about intellectual property (opens in a new window).

validations.isRequired: Type of intellectual property is required

questions.label: Do you have a model for generating revenue from your innovation?
What is the revenue model for your innovation?

validations.isRequired: Choose at least one revenue model

questions.label: Which NHS or social care organisation and department do you think would pay for the innovation?
questions.description: Be as specific as you can.

questions.label: Which NHS or social care organisation and department would benefit from the innovation?
questions.description: Be as specific as you can.

questions.label: Have you secured funding for the next stage of development?
Describe the funding you have secured for the next stage of development
questions.description: For example, venture capital, angel investor, seed funding, grant funding, government funding or similar.

questions.label: Do you know the cost of your innovation?
questions.description: By cost, we mean the cost to the NHS or any care organisation that would implement your innovation. Support organisations will use this to calculate cost effectiveness.

items.label: Yes, I have a detailed estimate
Yes, I have a rough idea

questions.label: What is the cost of your innovation?
questions.description:
Include the relevant metric such as a flat capital cost or cost per patient, cost per unit or cost per procedure. Include any costs associated with implementation and resources.

For example, £10 based on 500 units per site. £345 per procedure and a typical patient requires two procedures.

questions.label: Roughly how many patients would be eligible for your innovation in the UK?

items.label: 10,000 to half a million per year
More than half a million per year

questions.label: What is the eligibility criteria for your innovation?
questions.description:
For example, users need to be over a certain age, or have a certain medical history or current health status.

Answer "not relevant" if your innovation does not have any eligibility criteria.

questions.label: How many units of your innovation would you expect to sell in the UK per year?
Approximately how long do you expect each unit of your innovation to be in use?
questions.description: By this we mean the shelf life of the product, or the product's lifespan. This can include the lifespan of any components such as batteries.

questions.label: What are the costs associated with the use of your innovation, compared to current practice in the UK?

items.label: My innovation is cheaper to purchase
My innovation costs more to purchase, but has greater benefits that will lead to overall cost savings
My innovation costs more to purchase and has greater benefits, but will lead to higher costs overall

questions.label: Is your innovation ready for wider adoption across the health and care system?
questions.description: Find out more about commissioning and adoption (opens in a new window).

questions.label: Has your innovation been deployed in a NHS or care setting?
Where have you deployed your innovation?
questions.description: Provide the name of the organisation and the department, if possible.

questions.label: What was the commercial basis for deployment?
questions.description: For example, did you provide your innovation for free or was it purchased? Or was it part funded by yourself and the NHS area in which it's being deployed?

questions.label: How did the deployment of your innovation affect the organisation(s)?
questions.description: For example, which job roles were affected and how was the care pathway redesigned?

questions.label: Does your team have the resources for scaling up to national deployment?
questions.description: This includes having a team with the right combination of skills and knowledge.
